comment:
You're not being fair.  First, you are just hating on Heard because it's fashionable - she's no worse than any of the other actors, and better than some.  And Miller is the worst, but he did not ruin The Stand.  The Stand was trash as soon as the script was approved.  Then the director made it worse.  There's very little that an actor can do when the source material is this bad.  And even a great director is limited by the story, and this was not a great director.  
The entire cast could be replaced by Oscar winning actors, or by random people who have never acted , and the results would be the same.  Garbage in - garbage out.

comment:
*‚ÄùThis is someone who‚Äôs never dealt with severe mental illness‚Äù*

Say what you will about Ezra‚Äôs acting and other facets of their life, but to say that they‚Äôve never dealt with serious mental illness is just plain WRONG. Ezra has personally dealt with sexual abuse as a child and suicidal ideation stemming from the trauma of that abuse for most of their life. They also have adhd and anyone who has it or knows a person with it can tell you that it is not the easiest disorder to deal with. They may not be a schizophrenic person or someone who has worked with those that are but they have mental health struggles of their own that they deal with on a daily basis. Funny how you chose to skip over that or fail to research it in general.

Sounds like you‚Äôre just upset that they aren‚Äôt following the original story to a T and you‚Äôre just shitting on everything about it because of it.

comment: It would seem that more people actually "watched" AH just to downvote her or from some sort curiosity. As to The Stand, while an actor is certainly partly responsible for the performance they give, so is the director. While no expert, I'd think the end result is something between how they both understand character. Meaning that if Miller's portrayal had been completely NOT what the director had in mind, that would not have been the result. So I can't help but wonder really how much is really Miller's over the top portrayal and how much was the director's over the top vision of the character? Or maybe he got the role BECAUSE his way of portraying the character was in alignment with the director's vision for how the character should be played.

author: TheSporehacker

comment: Honestly,  Hollywood has NEVER been about diversity or inclusion. Hollywood is about making money. Period. To GUARANTEE that the millions of dollars spent on productions are not wasted, it is the job of the producers and directors to find the BEST talent they can to make the best product they can (to appeal to audiences). Just because a character may have a disability does NOT mean you need a disabled person to portray them. That goes for gay, trans, mentally ill, etc. An actor is someone who is hired to portray a certain character, and I for one am sick of all these advocacy groups telling actors they should not be playing a role with a disability, versus another person who has a disability. If these advocacy groups are that adamant about hiring practices, they can invest their own money in these projects and see how far it takes them. If the public wants to see/ support their casting choices, their project will make money. Otherwise, they should keep their advocacy / cancel culture threats to themselves.
